subject: Ethics
title: The Nothing-to-Hide Fallacy
description: A fast breakdown of The Nothing-to-Hide Fallacy for builders.

hook.text: Most people say 'I have nothing to hide' when asked about privacy. Sounds reasonable, right?

buildup.text: But try this: hand your unlocked phone to a stranger. Let them read every text and photo.

discovery.text: Privacy isn't about hiding wrongdoing. It's about controlling who knows what about you and when.

twist.text: Governments once tracked library checkouts to find 'suspicious' readers. Legal books, legal readers.

climax.text: 'Nothing to hide' assumes those in power always define 'wrong' the same way you do. They won't.

punchline.text: Privacy protects the innocent, not just the guilty.

quiz.question: What does the 'nothing to hide' argument overlook?
options: That surveillance costs are too high
That definitions of 'wrong' change with those in power
That encryption is too complex for most people
